top_categories.workout_context: Big Sugar Gravel's Ozark gravel, Punchy climbs forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 100 miles.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Big Sugar Gravel's demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before October.
95ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
At mile 60 of 100, glycogen is gone. This workout teaches your body to produce watts on fumes.
9,500ft of climbing means repeated surges above threshold. VO2max work is how you survive the fifth climb, not just the first.
At Big Sugar Gravel, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Big Sugar Gravel, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Big Sugar Gravel. Train it until it feels boring.
Short, max efforts are unavoidable. Punchy climbs, gap closures, attacks on ozark Mountain gravel with punchy repeated climbs. If you haven't trained them, you'll crack.
9,500ft of climbing on grades that change every minute. You need to switch from seated to standing without losing rhythm.
Endurance with intensity spikes baked in. Exactly what 9,500ft of climbing on ozark Mountain gravel with punchy repeated climbs does to your power file on race day.
Every hard session works better with a bigger aerobic base. At 100 miles, base fitness is the difference between racing and surviving.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for Big Sugar Gravel’s 100 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Big Sugar Gravel demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride ozark mountain gravel with punchy repeated climbs at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: ozark gravel, punchy climbs, technical descents. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 100 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Gravel Specific, Race Simulation, and TT Threshold to prepare you for 100 miles of ozark mountain gravel with punchy repeated climbs in Bentonville, Arkansas.
